answers.explanation:
The OCT GCIPL demonstrates notable loss of the ganglion cell and inner plexiform layer in the nasal portion OD and temporal quadrant OS, corresponding to a right visual field deficit OU, or right homonymous hemianopia.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: Based on the OCT images, what visual field defect do you expect the patient present with?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text: A right relative afferent pupillary defect was noted in the patient. Where does the lesion localize?

answers.explanation:
The optic tract is a white matter tract that is located between the optic chiasm and lateral genicular nucleus. Each optic tract contains the ipsilateral eye temporal retinal nerve fibers and contralateral eye nasal retinal nerve fibers. The optic tracts contain pupillary fibers unlike the optic radiations and visual cortex since the pupillary fibers leave for the midbrain from the distal portion of the optic tracts. Therefore, an RAPD is not expected in retrogeniculate lesions. The reason there is an RAPD contralateral to the optic tract lesion is because there are more fibers in the optic tract from the contralateral eye (classically 53:47) since the temporal visual field is larger than the nasal visual field. This ratio may be even larger for fibers serving the pupillary reflex.

![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-5-4.webp)

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Based on the retrochiasmal location of the lesion at the optic nerve tract, what type of deficit do you expect to see in OCT RNFL?

answers.explanation:
Bow tie atrophy is seen on RNFL OCT in retro-chiasmal lesions, where the nerve fiber layer is atrophied nasal and temporal in the eye contralateral to the lesion and superior and inferior in the eye ipsilateral to the lesion. This is due to the arrangement of the retinal nerve fibre layer as illustrated below.

![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-5-5.webp)
